page.title: 08FARMING IN GLADESTRY
page.content: The farms are small farms of between 90 and 300 acres. Most farmers keep sheep and cattle. Some farmers grow potatoes, swedes, and barley. A lot of the farms are made of two or more smaller farms. Most farms have grazing rights on the hills. In Spring there is lambing. In June there is silage and shearing. In July there is hill gathering. Then the sheep are dipped to keep off scab. In July and August there is hay-making. There are quite a lot of changes. Old fields have been ploughed and new sorts of grass planted. A lot of open hills have been ploughed to get rid of bracken. More people are making silage in big bags because it better for the sheep. There are lots of big new buildings so that more sheep can be kept under cover in winter. There are many new farm roads up to the hills.
